history.content: Before you take 189, I'd highly recommend taking some courses to develop some math fundamentals including CS 70, Math 53, EECS 126, and EECS 127. Apart from the ML side, you could try checking out a class like CS 186 (Databases) which can in theory be done with your background, but you'd probably get more out of it if you took 61C before it.

children.subject: 170 is a pretty fundamental course in terms of algorithm, both really useful for interviews and also for more theory (and proofs, etc.). 188 is also a pretty interesting course, but I think it's most important to get the fundamentals down first (i.e. 70, 61c, and then 170 and possibly 188) before 189
What are your thoughts on CS170 and CS188? I am on the waitlist for those and am curious about how they compare to CS186 or 189.

I think you should really prioritize taking 61c and cs70. Personally I think cs70 is not that great of a course, however the level of rigor is puts you through for critical thinking skills is really important for many courses (like 170, 189, etc), not to mention it teaches you the basics of probability and proofs needed for those CS courses as well. If your really sharp you could maybe pull off 170 and 188 without 70, but I would recommend this for like 98% of people, its just unneeded stress.  61c is also really important because it unlocks most course paths that have to do with anything below application level programming (like 162, 152, 151, 168,  etc) . I think once you take those courses, you would have a much better idea of what kind of courses you might want to take, and which ones you would like to avoid. 

When I was looking for courses to take, I would peek at the upcoming schedules (CS:https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Scheduling/CS/schedule-draft.html) (EE: https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Scheduling/EE/schedule-draft.html), and see what interested me. Currently taking a look at the CS one, I can see that you could maybe pull off CS160, but that class is notoriously difficult to get into unless you a senior. You might want to try CS169, however I havent really heard good things about that class in previous semesters, but supposedly they are restructuring it from the ground up, so you might wanna do a little more research to see what they've changed, and if that type of course suites you. I would snoop around the EECS101 Piazza about certain classes for more information. I also recommend you draft some sort of temporary schedule for yourself, trust me it makes figuring out courses and dealing with unexpected course situations a lot easier. It also lets you plan our what prereqs you need to complete. Best of luck!

CS 189 requires Math 53, Math 54 or EECS 16A+EECS 16B, and CS 70 for minimum. Professor Sahai will teach it this fall, which is more difficult. To take Professor Sahai's CS 189, you'd better take EECS 126 (or Stat 140 at minimum) and EECS 127 before it. CS 70 is important not only for probability but also for mathematical maturity. If you are a math major, I would say Math 55 is definitely not enough for CS 189. If you are a CS/EECS major, CS 61C is a great class to take because it prepares for 16x series courses and 152. Data 100 is easier than all other CS courses I have taken (I did not take Data 8), which does not represent the rigor of CS courses.

history.content: I've taken CS61A, 61B, and one upper div CS course(Data 100). I haven't decided which upper div CS course to take this fall and I am currently planning to take CS 189. Does anyone have any recommendations or suggestions for courses?
history.subject: Recommendations for Upper Div CS Course
